init_text:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: Yes, we do need to be aware of the possible side effects of excessive use of digital devices on our mental and physical health.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: we also need to be aware of the risks of staying disconnected from digital networks.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: afraid to stay connected in a meaningful way.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: If we do, we may lose an opportunity to provide meaningful support for each other while we all go through this experience together.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: having someone who is there for you during a crisis can make all the difference.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: the call was made on a laptop, a smartphone or an old fashioned telephone.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: don't, because it's the experience of connection, not the device itself, that matters most.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: It has been the only way I feel I have been able to stay connected with my family and friends around the world.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: in Thailand, and I work from home in London, but no matter how close we are or how many other ways we have to connect, being able

actions.text: ut no matter how close we are or how many other ways we have to connect, being able

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: lifeline for me to stay in touch with the people who mean the most in my life.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: in Thailand every year or so, but unfortunately due to the COVID pandemic, I have had to cancel all of my travel plans to visit them

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: no doubt for them as well.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: the apps that are available on the iPad to keep in touch with them.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: using Skype to chat to my mum whenever I can get a few minutes, and the FaceTime app has been a fantastic way for me to keep in

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: touch with my sister and my best friend in Thailand.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: My best friend got married on the 12th April this year, and I was so very sad that I couldn't attend.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: But using FaceTime, we were able to reconnect over the happy occasion and it meant the world to me to be included in that important day in my

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: I don't think I would have been able to feel so included if I hadn't had my iPad with me.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: in conclusion, I think we should update our thinking in terms of screen time during this period: With COVID in full swing, the risks of staying

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: digitally disconnected far outweigh the risks of staying digitally connected.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: we need to exercise a certain level of caution when it comes to staying connected and using our digital devices in an excessive and unsustainable way.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: folks who literally became housebound with their iPad, refusing to let it leave their side, letting it ruin their sleep and eating habits.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: we don't need to be so narrowly focused in trying to demonize the use of technology that is helping us stay connected during COVID.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: don't let it take over your life, but definitely don't let it stop you from making the most of your favourite apps and digital devices during this
